<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">FS-35<!-- /Folio -->

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">
<DIV align="right" style="font-size: 9pt; padding: 10px; margin-right: 50%">
<Font style="margin-top: 10pt">Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements<BR><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">
Millions of dollars, except per-share amounts</Font></Font></DIV>
<BR>&nbsp;
</DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,is -->

<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670232"></A>
</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 5</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Summarized Financial Data &#150; Chevron U.S.A. Inc.</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,body -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Chevron U.S.A. Inc. (CUSA)&nbsp;is a major subsidiary of Chevron Corporation. CUSA and its subsidiaries
manage and operate most of Chevron&#146;s U.S. businesses. Assets include those related to the
exploration and production of crude oil, natural gas and natural gas liquids and those associated
with the refining, marketing, supply and distribution of products derived from petroleum, excluding
most of the regulated pipeline operations of Chevron. CUSA also holds the company&#146;s investment in
the Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LLC joint venture, which is accounted for using the equity
method.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2008, Chevron implemented legal reorganizations in which certain Chevron subsidiaries
transferred assets to or under CUSA. The summarized financial information for CUSA and its
consolidated subsidiaries presented in the table below gives retroactive effect to the
reorganizations as if they had occurred on January&nbsp;1, 2008. However, the financial information in
the following table may not reflect the financial position and operating results in the future or
the historical results in the periods presented if the reorganization actually had occurred on that
date. The summarized financial information for CUSA and its consolidated subsidiaries is as
follows:</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,dn,"Summarized Financial Data Subsidiary One Table" -->
<DIV align="center">

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 6</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Summarized Financial Data &#150; Chevron Transport Corporation Ltd.</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,body -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Chevron Transport Corporation Ltd.
(CTC), incorporated in Bermuda, is an indirect, wholly owned subsidiary of Chevron Corporation. CTC
is the principal operator of Chevron&#146;s international tanker fleet and is engaged in the marine
transportation of crude oil and refined petroleum products. Most of CTC&#146;s shipping revenue is
derived from providing transportation services to other Chevron companies. Chevron Corporation has
fully and unconditionally guaranteed this subsidiary&#146;s obligations in connection with certain debt
securities issued by a third party. Summarized financial information for CTC and its consolidated
subsidiaries is as follows:</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<!-- xbrl -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; padding: 10px; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">
<Font style="margin-top: 10pt">&nbsp;
<BR>&nbsp;<BR>&nbsp;<BR>&nbsp;</Font></DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,is -->


<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670235"></A>
</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 8</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Lease Commitments</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Certain noncancelable leases are classified as capital leases, and the leased assets are included
as part of &#147;Properties, plant and equipment, at cost&#148; on the Consolidated Balance Sheet. Such
leasing arrangements involve tanker charters, crude oil production and processing equipment,
service stations, office buildings, and other facilities. Other leases are classified as operating
leases and are not capitalized. The payments on such leases are recorded as expense. Details of the
capitalized leased assets are as follows:</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,dn,"Capital Leases In Financial Statements Of Lessee Disclosure" -->
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 8pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="77%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD><!-- VRule -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 7pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right" colspan="7" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #0077c0">At December 31</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 7pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right" colspan="3"><B>2010</B></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right" colspan="2">2009</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="5" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Contingent rentals are based on factors other than the passage of time, principally sales
volumes at leased service stations. Certain leases include escalation clauses for adjusting rentals
to reflect changes in price indices, renewal options ranging up to 25&nbsp;years, and options to
purchase the leased property during or at the end of the initial or renewal lease period for the
fair market value or other specified amount at that time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670236"></A>
</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 9</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Fair Value Measurements</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Accounting standards for
fair value measurement (ASC 820) establish a framework for measuring fair
value and stipulate disclosures about fair value measurements. The standards apply to recurring and
nonrecurring financial and nonfinancial assets and liabilities that require or permit fair value
measurements. Among the required disclosures is the fair value hierarchy of inputs the company uses
to value an asset or a liability. The three levels of the fair value hierarchy are described as
follows:</DIV>




<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 4%">Level 1: Quoted prices (unadjusted)&nbsp;in active markets for identical assets and liabilities. For
the company, Level 1 inputs include exchange-traded futures contracts for which the parties are
willing to transact at the exchange-quoted price and marketable securities that are actively
traded.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 4%">Level 2: Inputs other than Level 1 that are observable, either directly or indirectly. For the
company, Level 2 inputs include quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities, prices obtained
through third-party broker quotes, and prices that can be corroborated with other observable
inputs for substantially the complete term of a contract.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 4%">Level 3: Unobservable inputs. The company does not use Level 3 inputs for any of its recurring
fair value measurements. Level 3 inputs may be required for the determination of fair value
associated with certain nonrecurring measurements of nonfinancial assets and liabilities. In
2010, the company used Level 3 inputs to determine the fair value of certain nonrecurring
nonfinancial assets.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>

<!-- xbrl,is -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-37<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV align="right" style="font-size: 8pt; padding: 10px; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">
<Font style="margin-top: 10pt; padding-left: 100px; margin-right: 50%">Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements</font><BR>
<Font style="margin-top: 0pt; padding-left: 137px; font-size: 7pt; margin-right: 50%">Millions of dollars, except per-share amounts
</Font></DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; padding: 10px; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7;">
<Font style="margin-top: 8pt"><b>Note 9</b> <FONT color="#000000">Fair Value Measurements - Continued</FONT><BR>&nbsp;</Font></DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,is -->


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value hierarchy for recurring assets and liabilities measured at fair value at
December&nbsp;31, 2010, and December&nbsp;31, 2009, is as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Assets and Liabilities Measured at Fair Value on a Recurring Basis</I>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,dn,"Fair Value Assets And Liabilities Measured On Recurring Basis Valuation Techniques" -->

    <TD colspan="10" align="left" style="border-top: 3px solid #0077C0">&nbsp;</TD>

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dn -->

<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Marketable
Securities </I></FONT>The company calculates fair value for its marketable securities based
on quoted market prices for identical assets and liabilities. The fair values reflect the cash that
would have been received if the instruments were sold at December&nbsp;31, 2010.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Derivatives </I></FONT>The
 company records its derivative instruments &#150; other than any commodity derivative
contracts that are designated as normal purchase and normal sale &#150; on the Consolidated Balance
Sheet at fair value, with virtually all the offsetting amount on the Consolidated Statement of
Income. For derivatives with identical or similar provisions as contracts that are publicly traded
on a regular basis, the company uses the market values of the publicly traded instruments as an
input for fair value calculations.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company&#146;s derivative instruments principally include crude oil, natural gas and refined
product futures, swaps, options and forward contracts. Derivatives classified as Level 1 include
futures, swaps and options contracts traded in active markets such as the New York Mercantile
Exchange.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Derivatives classified as Level 2 include swaps, options, and forward contracts principally
with financial institutions and other oil and gas companies, the fair values for which are obtained
from third-party broker quotes, industry pricing services and exchanges. The company obtains
multiple sources of pricing information for the Level 2 instruments. Since this pricing information
is generated from observable market data, it has historically been very consistent. The company does
not materially adjust this information. The company incorporates internal review, evaluation and
assessment procedures, including a comparison of Level 2 fair values derived from the company&#146;s
internally developed for-</DIV>


</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">ward curves (on a sample basis) with the pricing
information to document reasonable, logical and
supportable fair value determinations and proper level of classification.
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,dnap,"Impairment Or Disposal Of Long Lived Assets Policy" -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Impairments of &#147;Properties,
 plant and equipment&#148; </I></FONT>In accordance with the accounting standard for the
impairment or disposal of
<font style="white-space: nowrap">long-lived</font> assets (ASC 360), during 2010
and 2009 <font style="white-space: nowrap">long-lived</font>  assets &#147;held
and used&#148; with carrying amounts of $142 and $949 were written down to fair values of $57 and $490
resulting in  <font style="white-space: nowrap">before-tax</font> losses of $85 and $459, respectively. The fair values were determined from
internal cash flow models, using discount rates consistent with those used by the company to
evaluate cash flows of other assets of a similar nature.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Long-lived assets &#147;held for sale&#148; with carrying amounts of $49 and $160 were written down to a
fair value of $13 and $68, resulting in a before-tax loss of $36 and $92 in 2010 and 2009,
respectively. The fair values were determined based on bids received from prospective buyers and
from internal cash-flow models consistent with those used by the company to evaluate cash flows of
other assets of a similar nature.</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dnap -->

<!-- xbrl,dnap,"Accounting Standards For Fair Value Measurement Policy" -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Impairments of &#147;Investments and advances&#148; </I></FONT>In accordance with the accounting standards under the
equity method of accounting (ASC 323) and the cost method of accounting (ASC 325), during 2010 and
2009 investments with carrying amounts of $15 and $81 were written down to fair values of $0 and
$39 resulting in before-tax losses of $15 and $42, respectively. The fair values were determined
using discount rates consistent with those used by the company to evaluate cash flows of other
investments of a similar nature.
</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dnap -->

</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>

<!-- xbrl,is -->

<!-- /xbrl,dn -->

<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Assets and Liabilities Not Required to Be Measured at Fair Value </I></FONT>The company holds cash
equivalents and bank time deposits in U.S. and non-U.S. portfolios. The instruments classified as
cash equivalents are primarily bank time deposits with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or less and money
market funds. &#147;Cash and cash equivalents&#148; had carrying/fair values of $14,060 and $8,716 at
December&nbsp;31, 2010 and December&nbsp;31, 2009, respectively. The instruments held in &#147;Time deposits&#148; are
bank time deposits with maturities greater than 90&nbsp;days and had carrying/fair values of $2,855 at
December&nbsp;31, 2010. The fair values of cash, cash equivalents and bank time deposits reflect the cash
that would have been received or paid if the instruments were settled at year-end.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&#147;Cash and cash equivalents&#148; do not include investments with a carrying/fair value of $855 and
$123 at December&nbsp;31, 2010 and December&nbsp;31, 2009, respectively. These investments are restricted
funds related to an international upstream development project and U.S. refinery projects, which
are reported in &#147;Deferred charges and other assets&#148; on the Consolidated Balance Sheet. Long-term
debt of $5,636 and $5,705 had estimated fair values of $6,311 and $6,229 at December&nbsp;31, 2010 and
December&nbsp;31, 2009, respectively.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying values of short-term financial assets and liabilities on the balance sheet
approximate their fair values. Fair values of other financial instruments at the end of 2010 and
2009 were not material.</DIV>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670237"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 10</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Financial and Derivative Instruments
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Derivative Commodity Instruments </I></FONT>Chevron is exposed to market
risks related to price volatility of crude oil, refined products, natural gas, natural gas liquids,
liquefied natural gas and refinery feedstocks.</DIV>


</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company uses derivative commodity instruments to manage these exposures on a portion of
its activity, including firm commitments and anticipated transactions for the purchase, sale and
storage of crude oil, refined products, natural gas, natural gas liquids and feedstock for company
refineries. From time to time, the company also uses derivative commodity instruments for limited
trading purposes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company&#146;s derivative commodity instruments principally include crude oil, natural gas and
refined product futures, swaps, options, and forward contracts. None of the company&#146;s derivative
instruments is designated as a hedging instrument, although certain of the company&#146;s affiliates
make such designation. The company&#146;s derivatives are not material to the company&#146;s financial
position, results of operations or liquidity. The company believes it has no material market or
credit risks to its operations, financial position or liquidity as a result of its commodity
derivative activities.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company uses International Swaps and Derivatives Association agreements to govern
derivative contracts with certain counterparties to mitigate credit risk. Depending on the nature
of the derivative transactions, bilateral collateral arrangements may also be required. When the
company is engaged in more than one outstanding derivative transaction with the same counterparty
and also has a legally enforceable netting agreement with that counterparty, the net mark-to-market
exposure represents the netting of the positive and negative exposures with that counterparty and
is a reasonable measure of the company&#146;s credit risk exposure. The company also uses other netting
agreements with certain counterparties with which it conducts significant transactions to mitigate
credit risk.</DIV>


</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>

<!-- xbrl,is -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-39<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV align="right" style="font-size: 8pt; padding: 10px; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">
<Font style="margin-top: 10pt; padding-left: 100px; margin-right: 52%">Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements</Font><BR>
<Font style="font-size: 7pt; margin-top: 0pt; padding-left: 137px; margin-right: 52%">Millions of dollars, except per-share amounts
</Font></DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 7pt; padding: 10px; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; background: #E1EAF7">
<Font style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 10pt; color: #0077C0"><B>Note 10</B></Font> Financial and Derivative Instruments - Continued
<BR>&nbsp;</DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,is -->


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Derivative instruments measured at fair value at December&nbsp;31, 2010,  December&nbsp;31, 2009 and December 31, 2008, and
their classification on the Consolidated Balance Sheet and Consolidated Statement of Income are as
follows:
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Consolidated Balance Sheet: Fair Value of Derivatives Not Designated as Hedging Instruments</I>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,dn,"Consolidated Balance Sheet Fair Value Of Derivatives Not Designated As Hedging Instruments" -->
<DIV align="center">

<!-- /xbrl,dn -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Foreign Currency </I></FONT>The company may enter into currency derivative contracts to manage some of its
foreign currency exposures. These exposures include revenue and anticipated purchase transactions,
including foreign currency capital expenditures and lease commitments. The currency derivative
contracts, if any, are recorded at fair value on the balance sheet with resulting gains and losses
reflected in income. There were no open currency derivative contracts at December&nbsp;31, 2010 or 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Interest Rates </I></FONT>The company may enter into interest rate swaps from time to time as part of its
overall strategy to manage the interest rate risk on its debt. Interest rate swaps related to a
</DIV>

</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">portion of the company&#146;s fixed-rate debt, if any, may be accounted for as fair value hedges.
Interest rate swaps related to floating-rate debt, if any, are recorded at fair value on the
balance sheet with resulting gains and losses reflected in income. At year-end 2010 and 2009, the
company had no interest rate swaps.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Concentrations of Credit Risk </I></FONT>The company&#146;s financial instruments that are exposed to concentrations
of credit risk consist primarily of its cash equivalents, time deposits, marketable securities,
derivative financial instruments and trade receivables. The
company&#146;s <font style="white-space: nowrap">short-term</font> investments are
placed with a wide array of financial institutions with high credit ratings. These investment
policies limit the company&#146;s exposure both to credit risk and to concentrations of credit risk.
Similar policies on diversification and creditworthiness are applied to the company&#146;s
counterparties in derivative instruments.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The trade receivable balances, reflecting the company&#146;s diversified sources of revenue, are
dispersed among the company&#146;s broad customer base worldwide. As a result, the company believes
concentrations of credit risk are limited. The company routinely assesses the financial strength of
its customers. When the financial strength of a customer is not considered sufficient, requiring
Letters of Credit is a principal method used to support sales to customers.</DIV>


</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>

<!-- xbrl,is -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-40<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<!-- xbrl -->
<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; background: #E1EAF7">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 7pt; padding-top: 60px; padding-bottom: 10px; padding-left: 10px">
&nbsp;</DIV></DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,is -->



<p><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670238"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 0pt"><B>Note 11</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Operating Segments and Geographic Data
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,body -->

<!-- xbrl,dnap,"Accounting Standards For Segment Reporting Policy" -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Although each subsidiary of Chevron is responsible for its
own affairs, Chevron Corporation manages its investments in these subsidiaries and their
affiliates. The investments are grouped into two business segments, Upstream and Downstream,
representing the company&#146;s &#147;reportable segments&#148; and &#147;operating segments&#148; as defined in accounting
standards for segment reporting (ASC 280). Upstream operations consist primarily of exploring for,
developing and producing crude oil and natural gas; liquefaction, transportation and regasification
associated with liquefied natural gas (LNG); transporting crude oil by major international oil
export pipelines; processing, transporting, storage and marketing of natural gas; and a
gas-to-liquids project. Downstream operations consist primarily of refining of crude oil into
petroleum products; marketing of crude oil and refined products; transporting of crude oil and
refined products by pipeline, marine vessel, motor equipment and rail car; and manufacturing and
marketing of commodity petrochemicals, plastics for industrial uses, and fuel and lubricant
additives. All Other activities of the company include mining operations, power generation
businesses, worldwide cash management and debt financing activities, corporate administrative
functions, insurance operations, real estate activities, energy services, and alternative fuels and
technology.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The segments are separately managed for investment purposes under a structure that includes
&#147;segment managers&#148; who report to the company&#146;s &#147;chief operating decision maker&#148; (CODM) (terms as
defined in ASC 280). The CODM is the company&#146;s Executive Committee (EXCOM), a committee of senior
officers that includes the Chief Executive Officer, and EXCOM reports to the Board of Directors of
Chevron Corporation.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The operating segments represent components of the company, as described in accounting
standards for segment reporting (ASC 280), that engage in activities (a)&nbsp;from which revenues are
earned and expenses are incurred; (b)&nbsp;whose operating results are regularly reviewed by the CODM,
which makes decisions about resources to be allocated to the segments and assesses their
performance; and (c)&nbsp;for which discrete financial information is available.</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dnap -->


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment managers for the reportable segments are directly accountable to and maintain regular
contact with the company&#146;s CODM to discuss the segment&#146;s operating activities and financial
performance. The CODM approves annual capital and exploratory budgets at the reportable segment
level, as well as reviews capital and exploratory funding for major projects and approves major
changes to the annual capital and</DIV>


</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">exploratory budgets. However, business-unit managers within the operating segments are directly
responsible for decisions relating to project implementation and all other matters connected with
daily operations. Company officers who are members of the EXCOM also have individual management
responsibilities and participate in other committees for purposes other than acting as the CODM.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
activities reported in Chevron&#146;s upstream and downstream operating segments have changed effective January&nbsp;1, 2010. Chemicals businesses are now reported as part of the downstream segment.
In addition, the company&#146;s significant upstream-enabling operations, primarily a gas-to-liquids
project and major international export pipelines, have been reclassified from the downstream
segment to the upstream segment. Prior period information in this report has been revised to
conform to the 2010 presentation.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company&#146;s primary country of operation is the United States of America, its country of
domicile. Other components of the company&#146;s operations are reported as &#147;International&#148; (outside
the United States).</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Segment Earnings </I></FONT>The company evaluates the performance of its operating segments on an after-tax
basis, without considering the effects of debt financing interest expense or investment interest
income, both of which are managed by the company on a worldwide basis. Corporate administrative
costs and assets are not allocated to the operating segments. However, operating segments are
billed for the direct use of corporate services. Nonbillable costs remain at the corporate level in
&#147;All Other.&#148; Earnings by major operating area are presented in the following table:
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,dn,"Segment Earnings" -->
<DIV align="center">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD align="left" colspan="3">*&#147;All Other&#148; assets consist primarily of worldwide cash, cash equivalents, time deposits and

<!-- /xbrl,dn -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Segment Sales and Other Operating Revenues </I></FONT>Operating segment sales and other operating revenues,
including internal transfers, for the years 2010, 2009 and 2008, are presented in the table at
the right. Products are transferred between operating segments at internal product values that
approximate market prices.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues for the upstream segment are derived primarily from the production and sale of crude
oil and natural gas, as well as the sale of third-party production of natural gas. Revenues for the
downstream segment are derived from the refining and marketing of petroleum products such as
gasoline, jet fuel, gas oils, lubricants, residual fuel oils and other products derived from crude
oil. This segment also generates revenues from the manufacture and sale of additives for fuels and
lubricant oils and the transportation and trading of refined products, crude oil and natural gas
liquids. &#147;All Other&#148; activities include revenues from mining operations, power generation
businesses, insurance operations, real estate activities and technology companies.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other than the United States, no single country accounted for 10&nbsp;percent or more of the
company&#146;s total sales and other operating revenues in 2010, 2009 and 2008.</DIV>


</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-42<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<!-- xbrl -->
<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; background: #E1EAF7">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 7pt; padding-top: 60px; padding-bottom: 10px; padding-left: 10px">
&nbsp;</DIV></DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,is -->

<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670239"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 0pt"><B>Note 12</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Investments and Advances
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Equity in earnings, together with investments in and advances to companies accounted for using the
equity method and other investments accounted for at or below cost, is shown in the following
table. For certain equity affiliates, Chevron pays its share of some income taxes directly. For
such affiliates, the equity in earnings does not include these taxes, which are reported on the
Consolidated Statement of Income as &#147;Income tax expense.&#148;</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,dn,"Equity Earnings And Investments And Advances Under Equity Method At Or Below Cost" -->

<!-- /xbrl,dn -->


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Descriptions of major affiliates, including significant differences between the company&#146;s
carrying value of its investments and its underlying equity in the net assets of the affiliates,
are as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Tengizchevroil </I></FONT>Chevron has a 50&nbsp;percent equity ownership interest in Tengizchevroil (TCO), a joint
venture formed in 1993 to develop the Tengiz and Korolev crude oil fields in Kazakhstan over a
<font style="white-space: nowrap">40-year</font> period. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, the company&#146;s carrying value of its investment in TCO was
about
</DIV>

</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 49%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">$190 higher than the amount of underlying equity in TCO&#146;s net assets. This difference results from
Chevron acquiring a portion of its interest in TCO at a value greater than the underlying book
value for that portion of TCO&#146;s net assets. See Note 7, on page FS-36, for summarized financial
information for 100&nbsp;percent of TCO.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Petropiar </I></FONT>Chevron has a 30&nbsp;percent interest in Petropiar, a joint stock company formed in 2008 to
operate the Hamaca heavy-oil production and upgrading project. The project, located in Venezuela&#146;s
Orinoco Belt, has a 25-year contract term. Prior to the formation of Petropiar, Chevron had a 30
percent interest in the Hamaca project. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, the company&#146;s carrying value of its
investment in Petropiar was approximately $190 less than the amount of underlying equity in
Petropiar&#146;s net assets. The difference represents the excess of Chevron&#146;s underlying equity in
Petropiar&#146;s net assets over the net book value of the assets contributed to the venture.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Caspian Pipeline Consortium </I></FONT>Chevron has a 15&nbsp;percent interest in the Caspian Pipeline Consortium, a
variable interest entity, which provides the critical export route for crude oil from both TCO and
Karachaganak. The company joined the consortium in 1997 and has investments and advances totaling
$974 which includes long term loans of $1,046 at year-end 2010. The loans were provided to fund 30
percent of the pipeline construction. The company is not the primary beneficiary of the consortium
because it does not direct activities of the consortium and only receives its proportionate share
of the financial returns.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Petroboscan </I></FONT>Chevron has a 39&nbsp;percent interest in Petroboscan, a joint stock company formed in 2006
to operate the Boscan Field in Venezuela until 2026. Chevron previously operated the field under an
operating service agreement. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, the company&#146;s carrying value of its investment
in Petroboscan was approximately $250 higher than the amount of underlying equity in Petroboscan&#146;s
net assets. The difference reflects the excess of the net book value of the assets contributed by
Chevron over its underlying equity in Petroboscan&#146;s net assets.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Angola LNG Ltd. </I></FONT>Chevron has a 36&nbsp;percent interest in Angola LNG Ltd., which will process and
liquefy natural gas produced in Angola for delivery to international markets.
</DIV>

</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>

<!-- xbrl,is -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-43<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">

<DIV align="right" style="font-size: 9pt; padding: 10px; margin-right: 52%">
<Font style="margin-top: 10pt">Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
<FONT style="font-size: 7pt">Millions of dollars, except per-share amounts</Font></Font></DIV></DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 7pt; padding: 10px; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; background: #E1EAF7">
<Font style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 10pt; color: #0077C0"><B>Note 12</B></Font> Investments and Advances - Continued
<BR>&nbsp;</DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,is -->


<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>GS Caltex Corporation </I></FONT>Chevron owns 50&nbsp;percent of GS Caltex Corporation, a joint venture with
GS Holdings. The joint venture imports, refines and markets petroleum products and petrochemicals,
predominantly in South Korea.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LLC </I></FONT>Chevron owns 50&nbsp;percent of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company
LLC. The other half is owned by ConocoPhillips Corporation.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Star Petroleum Refining Company Ltd. </I></FONT>Chevron has a 64&nbsp;percent equity ownership interest in Star
Petroleum Refining Company Ltd. (SPRC), which owns the Star Refinery in Thailand. PTT Public
Company Limited owns the remaining 36&nbsp;percent of SPRC.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Caltex Australia Ltd. </I></FONT>Chevron has a 50&nbsp;percent equity ownership interest in Caltex Australia Ltd.
(CAL). The remaining 50&nbsp;percent of CAL is publicly owned. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, the fair value of
Chevron&#146;s share of CAL common stock was approximately $1,970.
</DIV>

</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Colonial Pipeline Company </I></FONT>In October&nbsp;2010, the company sold its 23.4&nbsp;percent equity interest in the
Colonial Pipeline Company.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Other Information </I></FONT>&#147;Sales and other operating revenues&#148; on the Consolidated Statement of Income
includes $13,672, $10,391 and $15,390 with affiliated companies for 2010, 2009 and 2008,
respectively. &#147;Purchased crude oil and products&#148; includes $5,559, $4,631 and $6,850 with affiliated
companies for 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&#147;Accounts and notes receivable&#148; on the Consolidated Balance Sheet includes $1,718 and $1,125
due from affiliated companies at December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, respectively. &#147;Accounts payable&#148;
includes $377 and $345 due to affiliated companies at December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table provides summarized financial information on a 100&nbsp;percent basis for all
equity affiliates as well as Chevron&#146;s total share, which includes Chevron loans to affiliates of
$1,543, $2,422 and $2,820 at December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.</DIV>

</DIV>

respectively.</TD>

<!-- /xbrl,dn -->

<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670241"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 0pt"><B>Note 14</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Litigation
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,body -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>MTBE </I></FONT>Chevron and many other companies in the petroleum industry have used methyl tertiary butyl
ether (MTBE)&nbsp;as a gasoline additive. Chevron is a party to 19 pending lawsuits and claims, the
majority of which involve numerous other petroleum marketers and refiners. Resolution of these
lawsuits and claims may ultimately require the company to correct or ameliorate the alleged effects
on the environment of prior release of MTBE by the company or other parties. Additional lawsuits
and claims related to the use of MTBE, including personal-injury
claims, may be filed in the future.
The company&#146;s ultimate exposure related to pending lawsuits and claims is not determinable, but
could be material to net income in any one period. The company no longer uses MTBE in the
manufacture of gasoline in the United States.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Ecuador</i></font>
 Chevron is a defendant in a civil lawsuit before the
Superior Court of Nueva Loja in Lago Agrio, Ecuador, brought in May&nbsp;2003 by plaintiffs who claim to
be representatives of certain residents of an area where an oil production consortium formerly had
operations. The lawsuit alleges damage to the environment from the oil exploration and production
operations and seeks unspecified damages to fund environmental remediation and restoration of the
alleged environmental harm, plus a health monitoring program. Until 1992, Texaco Petroleum Company (Texpet), a subsidiary of
Texaco Inc., was a minority
member of this consortium with Petroecuador, the Ecuadorian state-owned oil company, as the
majority partner; since 1990, the operations have been con-
</DIV>

</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">ducted solely by Petroecuador. At the
conclusion of the consortium and following an independent third-party environmental audit of the
concession area, Texpet entered into a formal agreement with the Republic of Ecuador and
Petroecuador for Texpet to remediate specific sites assigned by the government in proportion to
Texpet&#146;s ownership share of the consortium. Pursuant to that agreement, Texpet conducted a
three-year remediation program at a cost of $40. After certifying that the sites were properly
remediated, the government granted Texpet and all related corporate entities a full release from
any and all environmental liability arising from the consortium operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on the history described above, Chevron believes that this lawsuit lacks legal or
factual merit. As to matters of law, the company believes first, that the court lacks jurisdiction
over Chevron; second, that the law under which plaintiffs bring the action, enacted in 1999, cannot
be applied retroactively; third, that the claims are barred by the statute of limitations in
Ecuador; and, fourth, that the lawsuit is also barred by the releases from liability previously
given to Texpet by the Republic of Ecuador and Petroecuador and by the pertinent provincial and
municipal governments. With regard to the facts, the company believes that the evidence confirms
that Texpet&#146;s remediation was properly conducted and that the remaining environmental damage reflects Petroecuador&#146;s
failure to timely fulfill its
legal obligations and Petroecuador&#146;s further conduct since assuming full control over the
operations.

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2008, a mining engineer appointed by the court to identify and determine the cause of
environmental damage, and to specify steps needed to remediate it, issued a
</div>


</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-45<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">

<DIV align="right" style="font-size: 9pt; padding: 10px; margin-right: 52%">
<Font style="margin-top: 10pt">Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements<BR>
<FONT style="font-size: 7pt">Millions of dollars, except per-share amounts</Font></Font></DIV></DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; padding: 10px">
<Font style="margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 14</B></FONT><Font style="font-size: 7pt; color: #000000"> Litigation - Continued</Font></DIV></DIV>

<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">report recommending
that the court assess $18,900, which would, according to the engineer, provide financial
compensation for purported damages, including wrongful death claims, and pay for, among other
items, environmental remediation, health care systems and additional infrastructure for
Petroecuador. The engineer&#146;s report also asserted that an additional $8,400 could be assessed
against Chevron for unjust enrichment. In 2009, following the disclosure by Chevron of evidence
that the judge participated in meetings in which businesspeople and individuals holding themselves
out as government officials discussed the case and its likely outcome, the judge presiding over the
case was recused. In 2010, Chevron moved to strike the mining engineer&#146;s report and to dismiss the
case based on evidence obtained through discovery in the United States indicating that the report
was prepared by consultants for the plaintiffs before being presented as the mining engineer&#146;s
independent and impartial work and showing further evidence of misconduct. In August&nbsp;2010, the
judge issued an order stating that he was not bound by the mining engineer&#146;s report and requiring
the parties to provide their positions on damages within 45&nbsp;days. Chevron subsequently petitioned
for recusal of the judge, claiming that he had disregarded evidence of fraud and misconduct and
that he had failed to rule on a number of motions within the statutory time requirement.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;2010, Chevron submitted its position on damages, asserting that no amount should
be assessed against it. The plaintiffs&#146; submission, which relied in part on the mining engineer&#146;s
report, took the position that damages are between approximately $16,000 and $76,000 and that
unjust enrichment should be assessed in an amount between approximately $5,000 and $38,000. The next
day, the judge issued an order closing the evidentiary phase of the case and notifying the parties
that he had requested the case file so that he could prepare a judgment. Chevron petitioned to have
that order declared a nullity in light of Chevron&#146;s prior recusal petition, and because procedural
and evidentiary matters remain unresolved. In October&nbsp;2010, Chevron&#146;s motion to recuse the judge
was granted. A new judge took charge of the case and revoked the prior judge&#146;s order closing the
evidentiary phase of the case. On December&nbsp;17, 2010, the judge issued an order closing the
evidentiary phase of the case and notifying the parties that he had requested the case file so that
he could prepare a judgment. <BR>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chevron
and Texpet filed an arbitration claim in September&nbsp;2009 against the Republic of Ecuador
before the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague under the Rules of the United Nations Commission on
International Trade Law. The claim alleges violations of the Republic of Ecuador&#146;s
obligations under
the United States-Ecuador Bilateral Investment Treaty (BIT)&nbsp;and breaches of the settlement and
release agreements between the Republic of Ecuador and Texpet (described above), which are
investment agreements protected</DIV>





</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">by the BIT. Through the arbitration, Chevron and Texpet are seeking
relief against the Republic of Ecuador, including a declaration that any judgment against Chevron
in the Lago Agrio litigation constitutes a violation of Ecuador&#146;s obligations under the BIT. On
February&nbsp;9, 2011, the Permanent Court of Arbitration issued an Order for Interim Measures requiring
the Republic of Ecuador to take all measures at its disposal to suspend or cause to be suspended
the enforcement or recognition within and without Ecuador of any judgment against Chevron in the
Lago Agrio case pending further order of the Tribunal. Chevron expects to continue seeking
permanent injunctive relief and monetary relief before the Tribunal.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Through a series of recent U.S. court proceedings initiated by Chevron to obtain discovery
relating to the Lago Agrio litigation and the BIT arbitration, Chevron has obtained evidence that
it believes shows a pattern of fraud, collusion, corruption, and other misconduct on the part of
several lawyers, consultants and others acting for the Lago Agrio plaintiffs. In February&nbsp;2011,
Chevron filed a civil lawsuit in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York
against the Lago Agrio plaintiffs and several of their lawyers, consultants and supporters alleging
violations of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act
and other state laws. Through
the civil lawsuit, Chevron is seeking relief that includes an award of damages and a declaration
that any judgment against Chevron in the Lago Agrio litigation is the result of fraud and other
unlawful conduct and is therefore unenforceable. On February&nbsp;8, 2011, the Court issued a temporary
restraining order prohibiting the Lago Agrio plaintiffs and persons acting in concert with them
from taking any action in furtherance of recognition or enforcement of any judgment against Chevron
in the Lago Agrio case until March&nbsp;8, 2011. Chevron&#146;s motion for a preliminary injunction is presently before the Court.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On February&nbsp;14, 2011, the Provincial Court in Lago Agrio rendered an adverse judgment in the case.
The Provincial Court rejected Chevron&#146;s defenses to the extent the Court addressed them in its
opinion. The judgment assesses approximately $8,600 in damages and about $900 for the plaintiffs&#146;
representatives. It also assesses an additional amount of approximately $8,600 in punitive damages
unless the company provides a public apology. Chevron continues to believe the Court&#146;s judgment is
illegitimate and unenforceable in Ecuador, the United States and other countries. The company also
believes the judgment is the product of fraud, and contrary to the legitimate scientific evidence.
Chevron will appeal this decision in Ecuador. Chevron cannot predict the timing or ultimate
outcome of the appeals process in Ecuador. Chevron will continue a vigorous defense of any
imposition of liability. Because Chevron has no substantial assets in Ecuador, Chevron would
expect enforcement actions  as a result of this judgment to be brought in other jurisdictions.
Chevron  expects to contest any such actions.
</DIV>


</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-46<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; background: #E1EAF7">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 7pt; padding-top: 60px; padding-bottom: 10px; padding-left: 10px">
<Font style="font-size: 8pt; color: #0077C0"><B>Note 14</B></FONT> Litigation - Continued</DIV></DIV>



<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The ultimate outcome of the foregoing matters, including any financial effect on Chevron,
remains uncertain.


Management does not believe an estimate of a reasonably possible loss (or a
range of loss) can be made in this case. Due to the defects
associated with the judgment, the 2008
engineer&#146;s report and the September&nbsp;2010 plaintiffs&#146; submission, management does not believe these
documents have any utility in calculating a reasonably possible loss (or a range of loss).
Moreover, the highly uncertain legal environment surrounding the case provides no basis for
management to estimate a reasonably possible loss (or a range of loss).</DIV>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670242"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 15</B>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Taxes

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2010, before-tax income for U.S. operations, including related corporate and other charges, was
$6,528, compared with before-tax income of $1,310 and $10,765 in 2009 and 2008, respectively. For
international operations, before-tax income was $25,527, $17,218 and $32,292 in 2010, 2009 and
2008, respectively. U.S. federal income tax expense was reduced by $162, $204 and $198 in 2010,
2009 and 2008, respectively, for business tax credits.
</DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,dn -->



</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">




<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company&#146;s effective tax rate decreased from 43.0&nbsp;percent in 2009 to 40.3&nbsp;percent in 2010.
The rate was lower in 2010 than in 2009 primarily due to international upstream impacts. A lower
effective tax rate in international upstream in 2010 was primarily driven by an increased
utilization of tax credits, which had a greater impact on the rate than one-time deferred tax
benefits and relatively low tax rates on asset sales in 2009. Also, a smaller portion of company
income was earned in higher tax rate international upstream jurisdictions in 2010 than in 2009.
Finally, foreign currency remeasurement impacts caused a reduction in the effective tax rate
between periods.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company records its deferred taxes on a tax-jurisdiction basis and classifies those net
amounts as current or noncurrent based on the balance sheet classification of the related assets or
liabilities. The reported deferred tax balances are composed of the following:</DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,dn -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred tax liabilities at the end of 2010 increased by almost $1,400 from year-end 2009. The
increase was primarily related to increased temporary differences for property, plant and
equipment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred tax assets increased by approximately $700 in 2010. Increases primarily related to
additional foreign tax credits arising from earnings in high-tax-rate international jurisdictions (which were
substantially offset by valuation allowances) and to increased temporary differences for asset
retirement obligations, environmental reserves and employee benefits. These effects were partially
offset by reductions in deferred credits resulting primarily from the usage of tax benefits in
international tax jurisdictions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The overall valuation allowance relates to deferred tax assets for foreign tax credit
carryforwards, tax loss carryforwards and temporary differences. It reduces the deferred tax assets
to amounts that are, in management&#146;s assessment, more likely than not to be realized. Tax loss
carryforwards
<!-- xbrl,is -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income taxes are not accrued for unremitted earnings of international operations that have
been or are intended to be reinvested indefinitely. Undistributed earnings of international
consolidated subsidiaries and affiliates for which no deferred income tax provision has been made
for possible future remittances totaled $21,347 at December&nbsp;31, 2010. This amount represents
earnings reinvested as part of the company&#146;s ongoing international business. It is not practicable
to estimate the amount of taxes that might be payable on the eventual remittance of earnings that
are intended to be reinvested indefinitely. At the end of 2010, deferred income taxes were recorded
for the undistributed earnings of certain international operations for which the company no longer
intends to indefinitely reinvest the earnings. The company does not anticipate incurring significant
additional taxes on remittances of earnings that are not indefinitely reinvested.
</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,dnap,"Income Tax Policy" -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Uncertain Income Tax Positions </I></FONT>Under accounting standards for uncertainty in income taxes (ASC
740-10), a company recognizes a tax benefit in the financial statements for an uncertain tax
position only if management&#146;s assessment is that the position is &#147;more likely than not&#148; (i.e., a
likelihood greater than 50&nbsp;percent) to be allowed by the tax jurisdiction based solely on the
technical merits of the position. The term &#147;tax position&#148; in the accounting standards for income
taxes
(ASC
740-10-20) refers to a position in a previously filed tax return or a position expected to be
taken in a future tax return that is reflected in measuring current or deferred income tax assets
and liabilities for interim or annual periods.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table indicates the changes to the company&#146;s unrecognized tax benefits for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009 and 2008. The term &#147;unrecognized tax benefits&#148; in the
accounting standards for income taxes (ASC 740-10-20) refers to the differences between a tax
position taken or expected to be taken in a tax return and the benefit measured and recognized in
the financial statements. Interest and penalties are not included.</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dnap -->



</DIV>

<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Balance at December 31</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left"><B>$</B></TD>
    <TD align="right"><B>3,507</B></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD style="border-right: 1px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">3,195</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">2,696</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="5" align="left" style="border-top: 3px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" style="border-right: 0px solid #0077c0; border-top: 3px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>    <TD align="left" style="border-top: 3px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="left" style="border-top: 3px solid #0077C0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dn -->


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately 80&nbsp;percent of the $3,507 of unrecognized tax benefits at December&nbsp;31, 2010,
would have an impact on the effective tax rate if subsequently recognized. Certain of these
unrecognized tax benefits relate to tax carryforwards that may require a full valuation allowance
at the time of any such recognition.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tax positions for Chevron and its subsidiaries and affiliates are subject to income tax audits
by many tax jurisdictions throughout the world. For the company&#146;s major tax jurisdictions,
examinations of tax returns for certain prior tax years had not been completed as of December&nbsp;31,
2010. For these jurisdictions, the latest years for which income tax examinations had been
finalized were as follows: United States &#150; 2005, Nigeria &#150;
1994, Angola &#150; 2001 and Saudi Arabia
&#150; 2003.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company engages in ongoing discussions with tax authorities regarding the resolution of tax
matters in the various jurisdictions. Both the outcome of these tax matters and the timing of
resolution and/or closure of the tax audits are highly uncertain. However, it is reasonably
possible that developments on tax matters in certain tax jurisdictions may result in significant
increases or decreases in the company&#146;s total unrecognized tax benefits within the next 12&nbsp;months.
Given the number of years that still remain subject to examination and the number of matters being
examined in the various tax jurisdictions, we are unable to estimate the range of possible adjustments to the balance of unrecognized tax
benefits.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On the Consolidated Statement of Income, the company reports interest and penalties related to
liabilities for uncertain tax positions as &#147;Income tax expense.&#148; As of December&nbsp;31, 2010, accruals
of $225 for anticipated interest and penalty obligations were included on the Consolidated Balance
Sheet, compared with accruals of $232 as of year-end 2009. Income tax expense (benefit)&nbsp;associated
with interest and penalties was $40, $(20) and $79 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.</DIV>



</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>

<!-- xbrl,is -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-48<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">4,574</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Reclassified to long-term debt</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right"><B>(5,400</B></TD>
    <TD nowrap><B>)</B></TD>
    <TD style="border-right: 1px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="left">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">(4,190</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 1px">
    <TD colspan="5" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" style="border-right: 1px solid #0077c0; border-top: 1px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" style="border-top: 1px solid #0077C0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="background: #ffffff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Total short-term debt</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left"><B>$</B></TD>
    <TD align="right"><B>187</B></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD style="border-right: 1px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">384</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD colspan="5" align="left" style="border-top: 3px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="left" style="border-right: 0px solid #0077c0; border-top: 3px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>    <TD align="left" style="border-top: 3px solid #0077c0">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>




<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 7pt">
<TR>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="98"></TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">*</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Weighted-average interest rates at December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, were 0.16&nbsp;percent and 0.08
percent, respectively.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dn -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Redeemable long-term obligations consist primarily of <font style="white-space: nowrap">tax-exempt</font> variable-rate put bonds that are
included as current liabilities because they become redeemable at the option of the bondholders
within one year following the balance sheet date.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">In 2010, $1,250 of tax-exempt bonds related to projects at the Pascagoula and El Segundo refineries
were issued.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The company periodically enters into interest rate swaps on a portion of its short-term debt.
At December&nbsp;31, 2010, the company had no interest rate swaps on short-term debt.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2010, the company had $6,000 in committed credit facilities with various major
banks, expiring in May&nbsp;2013, that enable the refinancing of short-term obligations on a long-term
basis. These facilities support commercial paper borrowing and can also be used for general
corporate </div>

</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">purposes. The company&#146;s practice has been to continually replace expiring commitments with
new commitments on substantially the same terms, maintaining levels management believes
appropriate. Any borrowings under the facilities would be unsecured indebtedness at interest rates
based on the London Interbank Offered Rate or an average of base lending rates published by
specified banks and on terms reflecting the company&#146;s strong credit rating. No borrowings were
outstanding under these facilities at December&nbsp;31, 2010.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009, the company classified $5,400 and $4,190, respectively, of
short-term debt as long-term. Settlement of these obligations is not expected to require the use of
working capital within one year, as the company has both the intent and the ability, as evidenced
by committed credit facilities, to refinance them on a long-term basis.</DIV>


<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670244"></A>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 17</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Long-Term Debt
</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#F56670tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<!-- xbrl -->

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">
<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">
<DIV align="right" style="font-size: 9pt; padding: 10px; margin-right: 52%">
<Font style="margin-top: 10pt">Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements<BR><FONT style="font-size: 8pt">
Millions of dollars, except per-share amounts</Font></Font></DIV></DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; background: #E1EAF7">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 9pt; padding: 10px; margin-right: 52%">
&nbsp;</DIV></DIV>

<!-- /xbrl,is -->

<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">


<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670245"></A>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 18</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">New Accounting Standards
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,body -->

<!-- xbrl,dnap,"Transfers And Servicing Of Financial Assets Policy" -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><FONT color="#E51837"><I>Transfers
and Servicing (ASC 860), Accounting for Transfers of Financial Assets (ASU 2009-16) </I></FONT>The
FASB issued ASU 2009-16 in December&nbsp;2009. This standard became effective for the company on January
1, 2010. ASU 2009-16 changes how companies account for transfers of financial assets and eliminates
the concept of qualifying special-purpose entities. Adoption of the guidance did not have an effect
on the company&#146;s results of operations, financial position or liquidity.</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dnap -->

<!-- xbrl,dnap,"Consolidation Policy_#2" -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT color="#E51837"><I>Consolidation (ASC 810), Improvements to Financial Reporting by Enterprises Involved With
Variable Interest Entities <font style="white-space: nowrap">(ASU
2009-17)</font> </I></font> The FASB issued ASU 2009-17 in December&nbsp;2009. This standard
became effective for the company January&nbsp;1, 2010. ASU 2009-17 requires the enterprise to
qualitatively assess if it is the primary beneficiary of a variable-interest entity (VIE), and if
so, the VIE must be consolidated. Adoption of the standard did not have an impact on the company&#146;s
results of operations, financial position or liquidity.</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dnap -->

<!-- xbrl,dnap,"Receivables Policy" -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<FONT color="#E51837"><I>Receivables (ASC 310), Disclosures about the Credit Quality of Financing Receivables and the
Allowance for Credit Losses <font style="white-space: nowrap">(ASU
2010-20)</font> </I></font> In July&nbsp;2010, the FASB issued ASU 2010-20, which became
effective with the company&#146;s reporting at December&nbsp;31, 2010. This standard amends and expands
disclosure requirements about the credit quality of financing receivables and the related allowance
for credit losses. As a result of these amendments, companies are required to disaggregate, by
portfolio segment or class of financing receivable, certain existing disclosures and provide
certain new disclosures about financing receivables and related allowance for credit losses.
Adoption of the standard did not change the company&#146;s existing disclosures.</DIV>
<!-- /xbrl,dnap -->

<DIV align="left">
<A name="F56670246"></A>
</DIV>

<!-- xbrl,n -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 12pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0; margin-top: 10pt"><B>Note 19</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 8pt; margin-top: 0pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; color: #0077C0">Accounting for Suspended Exploratory Wells
</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,body -->

<!-- xbrl,dnap,"Industry Specific Policies Oil And Gas" -->
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Accounting standards for the costs of exploratory wells
(ASC 932) provide that exploratory well costs continue to be capitalized after the completion of
drilling when (a)&nbsp;the well has found a sufficient quantity of reserves to justify completion as a
producing well and (b)&nbsp;the entity is making sufficient progress assessing the reserves and the
economic and operating viability of the project. If either condition is not met or if an enterprise
obtains information that raises substantial doubt about the economic or operational viability of the project, the exploratory well would be assumed
to be impaired, and its costs, net of any salvage value, would be charged to expense. (Note that an
entity is not required to complete the exploratory or exploratory-type stratigraphic well as a
producing well.) The accounting standards provide a number of indicators that can assist an entity
in demonstrating that sufficient progress is being made in assessing the reserves and economic</DIV>


</DIV>
<DIV style="position: relative; float: right; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">viability of the project.<!-- /xbrl,dnap --> The following table indicates the changes to the company&#146;s suspended
exploratory well costs for the three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2010:
</DIV>


<!-- xbrl,dn,"Suspended Well Costs Disclosure" -->
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 8pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">

<!-- /xbrl,dn -->

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of the $2,299 of exploratory well costs capitalized for more than one year at December&nbsp;31,
2010, $982 (26 projects) is related to projects that had drilling activities under way or firmly
planned for the near future. The $1,317 balance is related to 27 projects in areas requiring a major
capital expenditure before production could begin and for which additional drilling efforts were
not under way or firmly planned for the near future. Additional drilling was not deemed necessary
because the presence of hydrocarbons had already been established, and other activities were in
process to enable a future decision on project development.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The projects for the $1,317 referenced above had the following activities associated with
assessing the reserves and the projects&#146; economic viability: (a) $501 (three projects) &#150; project
sanction approved and construction is in progress, with initial recognition of proved reserves expected upon
 reaching &#147;economic producibility&#148; per SEC guidelines;
(b) $263 (six projects) &#150; development alternatives under review;
(c) $178 (three projects) &#150; in
process of entering contracts for front-end engineering and design;
(d) $154 (three projects) &#150;
progression of development concept selection and unitization agreement; (e) $109 (five projects)
&#150; undergoing front-end
engineering
<!-- xbrl,is -->
</DIV>


</DIV>
<BR clear="all"><BR>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif"><!-- Folio -->FS-50<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; background: #E1EAF7">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 7pt; padding-top: 60px; padding-bottom: 10px; padding-left: 10px">
<Font style="font-size: 8pt; color: #0077c0"><b>Note 19</b></font>
Accounting for Suspended Exploratory Wells - Continued</DIV></DIV>

<P><DIV style="position: relative; float: left; width: 48%">
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">
<!-- /xbrl,is -->
and design with final investment
decision expected in 2011; (f) $73 (two projects) &#150; development concept under review by
 government; $39 &#150; miscellaneous
activities for five projects with smaller amounts suspended. While progress was being made on all
53 projects, the decision on the recognition of proved reserves under SEC rules in some cases may
not occur for several years because of the complexity, scale and negotiations connected with the
projects. The majority of these decisions are expected to occur in the next three years.</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The $2,299 of suspended well costs capitalized for a period greater than one year as of
December&nbsp;31, 2010, represents 176 exploratory wells in 53
projects. The tables below contain the
aging of these costs on a well and project basis:</DIV>
